Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the percentage of children born in developing countries who die of cancer each year. The actual statistic is that only 20% of children with cancer in developing countries are cured, not that 80% die.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that only 20% of children with cancer in developing countries are cured, as stated by the World Health Organization.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it misquotes and misinterprets the World Health Organization's findings on childhood cancer survival rates.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the percentage of children cured of cancer can be applied to the entire population of children born in developing countries.
Falters at times: The claim falters by misquoting and misrepresenting the statistics on childhood cancer survival rates.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the higher mortality rate of childhood cancer in developing countries, such as limited access to healthcare or resources.
Understate: The claim understates the actual survival rate of children with cancer in developing countries, which is 20% rather than the exaggerated 80% mortality rate.
